channel.title: Ecma International-relevant MDN issues
channel.description: Issue filed on MDN Web Docs related to pages attached to technologies developed by Ecma International

item.title: [ecmascript] Typo
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Classes

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Classes#evaluation_order

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The initializer is evaluated during instance creation, at the start of the constructor (for base classes) or immediately before the super() call returns (for derived classes).

What did you expect to see?

The initializer is evaluated during instance creation, at the start of the constructor (for base classes) or immediately after the super() call returns (for derived classes).

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

Only when parent class is fully initialized and returns, child class initializers starts evaluated and added fields to 'this'.

// Order of evaluation and initialization of fields in parent and child classes
// Definition of ParentClassEvaluation
class ParentClassEvaluation {
  // Step 1: Initialization of the instance field in the parent class, when the field initializer expression is assigned to the field
  // Here, the initializer expression for parentField is saved.
  parentField = "parentInitializer";
  
  // Step 2: Definition of the parent class constructor
  constructor(firstName) {
    // This is invoked during instance creation.
    // Evaluating the initializer: This is the moment when, during instance creation, the initializer expression is actually executed and assigned to the field. Thus, at this stage, the initializer expression "parentInitializer" is assigned to the field parentField.
    // this.parentField and this.firstName are available here.
    this.firstName = firstName;
    this.parentField = "newParentField"; // Here, parentField is reassigned.
  }
}

// Definition of ChildClassEvaluation (subclass of ParentClassEvaluation)
class ChildClassEvaluation extends ParentClassEvaluation {
  // Step 3: Initialization of the instance field in the child class, when the field initializer expression is assigned to the field
  // Here, the initializer expression for childField is saved.
  childField = "childInitializer";
  
  // Step 4: Definition of the child class constructor
  constructor(firstName, secondName) {
    // Step 5: super() is called to initialize the parent class
    super(firstName);
    
    // this.parentField and this.firstName are already initialized and available.
    // After returning from super(), the fields of the current class are initialized.
    // Evaluating the initializer: This is the moment when, during instance creation, the initializer expression is actually executed and assigned to the field. Thus, at this stage, the initializer expression "childInitializer" is assigned to the field childField.
    // this.childField is available here.
    this.secondName = secondName; // secondName is initialized.
    this.childField = "newChildField"; // childField is reassigned here.
  }
}

// Step 6: Creating an instance of ChildClassEvaluation
const instanceFromChildClassEvaluation = new ChildClassEvaluation('Vladimir', 'Borovikov');

// Step 7: Logging the instance to see the field values
console.log(
  "instanceFromChildClassEvaluation",
  instanceFromChildClassEvaluation
);

/* Step-by-step evaluation:

  1. Initialization of the parent class field (before constructor):

parentField is initialized with the value "parentInitializer".
Note: This happens before the ParentClassEvaluation constructor is executed.

  1. Execution of the parent class constructor:

The ParentClassEvaluation constructor is called with the parameter firstName.
The initializer expression "parentInitializer" is assigned to the field parentField.
this.firstName is assigned the value of the firstName parameter ("Vladimir").
this.parentField is reassigned with the value "newParentField".

  1. Initialization of the child class field (before constructor):

childField is initialized with the value "childInitializer".
Note: This happens before the ChildClassEvaluation constructor is executed.

  1. Execution of the child class constructor:

The ChildClassEvaluation constructor is called with the parameters firstName and secondName.
super(firstName) is called, which executes the ParentClassEvaluation constructor, as described in Step 2.
After returning from super(firstName), the initializer expression "childInitializer" is assigned to the field childField, this.secondName is assigned the value of the secondName parameter ("Borovikov").
this.childField is reassigned with the value "newChildField".

Final object structure:

instanceFromChildClassEvaluation will have the following fields:
parentField: 'newParentField',
firstName: 'Vladimir',
childField: 'newChildField',
secondName: 'Borovikov'

When we log the instance to the console, the result will be:

instanceFromChildClassEvaluation {
parentField: 'newParentField',
firstName: 'Vladimir',
childField: 'newChildField',
secondName: 'Borovikov'
}

This breakdown shows how instance fields are initialized and the order of constructor logic execution for base and derived classes in JavaScript.

MDN metadata

Page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/javascript/reference/classes
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Classes
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/javascript/reference/classes/index.md
  • Last commit: 1b2c87c
  • Document last modified: 2024-07-25T21:53:55.000Z

item.title: [ecmascript, streams] ReadableStreamDefaultController: undocumented error conditions
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/ReadableStreamDefaultController/close

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Exceptions

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The "Exceptions" section says:

TypeError
Thrown if the source object is not a ReadableStreamDefaultController.

This suggests that errors are not thrown in other cases.

What did you expect to see?

I expect to see that a TypeError may be thrown by this method if the stream is already in the process of closing or closed.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

https://streams.spec.whatwg.org/#rs-default-controller-close

Do you have anything more you want to share?

Similar issues exist for ReadableStreamDefaultController.enqueue and probably methods on WritableStreamDefaultController as well.

MDN metadata

Page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/readablestreamdefaultcontroller/close
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/ReadableStreamDefaultController/close
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/readablestreamdefaultcontroller/close/index.md
  • Last commit: d8b4431
  • Document last modified: 2024-04-22T06:16:40.000Z

item.title: [ecmascript] Import assertions proposal renamed to import attributes
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Statements/import

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

No response

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

That page mention import assertions, with the import ... assert { ... } syntax.

What did you expect to see?

The proposal has been renamed to "import attributes", and the keyword has been replaced from assert to with. assert is now "deprecated and should not be relied upon".

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

https://tc39.es/proposal-import-attributes/, specifically https://tc39.es/proposal-import-attributes/#sec-deprecated-assert-keyword-for-import-attributes.

Do you have anything more you want to share?

Chrome is the only browser implementing assert (and V8-based platforms).

Chrome implements with under a flag (and V8-based platforms), Safari implements with in TP and Firefox is implementing it.

The proposal update comes also with some semantic changes, however these details have never been documented so there is no change needed to the docs:

  • invalid attribute keys are now disallowed, rather than silently ignored
  • JSON and CSS modules are fetched with the appropriate HTTP headers (whatwg/html#9486)

item.title: [ecmascript] Macrotasks and Microtasks
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/await

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Control flow effects of await

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

When an await is encountered in code (either in an async function or in a module), the awaited expression is executed, while all code that depends on the expression's value is paused and pushed into the microtask queue. The main thread is then freed for the next task in the event loop...

For me, The main thread is then freed for the next task in the event loop, sounds like that next task from macrotask queue will be executed before any microtask that was pushed into the microtask queue.

What did you expect to see?

The main thread is then freed for the next task in the event loop which will be executed after any microtask e.g. code that depends on the expression's value.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

https://javascript.info/event-loop#macrotasks-and-microtasks

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

MDN metadata

Page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/javascript/reference/operators/await
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/await
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/javascript/reference/operators/await/index.md
  • Last commit: 3c33463
  • Document last modified: 2023-06-29T17:06:46.000Z

item.title: [ecmascript] Misleading information around await's interaction with microtask/task queues
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/await

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Control flow effects of await

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

...all code that depends on the expression's value is paused and pushed into the microtask queue.

await does not inherently push anything into the microtask queue, at least not unless the promise being awaited is already settled. The microtask queue is where promise tasks go after the promise is settled. await simply pauses the function. The microtask of resuming the function is added to the queue when the promise ultimately settles.

The "microtask queue" link to the EventLoop page also has no mention of the microtask queue.

The main thread is then freed for the next task in the event loop. This happens even if the awaited value is an already-resolved promise or not a promise.

This only happens if the promise is not already settled (or does not get settled within further execution of the current task). If settled, function continuation is added to the microtask queue and the current task of the event loop continues to run until its microtask queue is empty. You can create an event loop-blocking async function demonstrating this

// blocks the event loop
async function loop(){
  await Promise.resolve()
  loop()
}
loop()

Despite the use of await, the main thread is not freed to run the next task.

What did you expect to see?

A more accurate description await and its interactions with the task and microtask queues.

The microtask link is probably better directed to:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTML_DOM_API/Microtask_guide
(see comment below)

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTML_DOM_API/Microtask_guide

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

MDN metadata

Page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/javascript/reference/operators/await
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/await
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/javascript/reference/operators/await/index.md
  • Last commit: 0e1f404

item.title: [ecmascript] Need a page on Execution context
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/this

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

I didn't know where exactly to post the issue. I went for "this" cause the value of "this" is strictly related to the execution context.

Specific section or headline?

What did you expect to see?

Did you test this? If so, how?
